my name is Matt Klein I'm a software engineer from lift Ivete our networking team here so we
obviously work a lot on envoy a but we also do a bunch of other things related just to general networking within lists
like DNS and dealing with AWS and all those fun things so today we'll be
talking about envoy so before we actually dive into envoy I'm just going
to spend a minute or two kind of giving an overview of the state of micro service networking so kind of when you
look around the landscape right now we have a lot of people that are starting to kind of ramp up on micro service
architectures and that's leading to frankly a lot of chaos and that involves
a whole bunch different components so we have a lot of languages and frameworks it's very uncommon these days for
companies to you know be able to use only Java or only C++ now we have
companies that are building services and four or five different languages we
obviously have a lot of different protocols you know we have rest and they all we have databases and caching we
have binary prototype protocols so there's just lots of different protocols floating around we have a huge variety
of different structures so we have people that are still running bare metal on premise we
have you know people that are running on against we have people that are running on containers now we have functions to
service so huge variety then there's obviously all the load balancers and
these again range from your old-school proprietary hardware boxes to cloud
vendor solutions to software appliances and probably most importantly out of all
these different systems you know we have a huge variety in what comes out so we
have stats we have tracing Liat logging most people don't even app tracing but the idea here is that you know given
your large variety of languages and frameworks and protocols and infrastructures load balancers you're
likely getting different stats different tracing and different logging out of all these components so it's incredibly
difficult to understand what's actually going on on top of that you know we have
these kind of distributed systems networking best practices you know and those include things like retry circuit
breaking rate limiting timeouts and these are things that we all know that we're supposed to do but the honest
reality is that a lot of people have partial implementations they might have broken implementations they might not
have any implementations and most importantly they have different implementations particularly based on
whatever language and whatever framework are actually using then we get into
authentication and authorization where a lot of people don't have anything some
people are using basic auth some people have a very complicated mutual TLS based system so there's a there's a huge
variety here in terms of authorization you know people are doing very simple role based systems to hugely complicated
policy language systems and on top of all of this and this is somewhat related
to languages and frameworks we have lots of different libraries you know a need libraries range from very simple
libraries like the curl library and PHP to libraries like finagle you know that
are that are very complicated and to have lots of different things in them but the idea here again is that these
libraries you know they range in and complex see they range in features and they
output different stats and you know for companies that are programming in four
or five or six different languages if they want to have robust system they then have to actually go through and you
know they have to implement all of these features and their four or five different libraries so that yields this
which is the really big and confusing mess and what I like to tell people or you know it is that everyone wants their
micro service architecture but what it really comes down to at the end of the day you know from my perspective is good
observability and quality networking and what I typically find is that people that don't have these things they get
very frustrated and they don't trust the network and then they don't feel that the micro service architecture is
actually appropriate for them and then they abort and this is a problem that I've seen many many times so getting
into ongoing you know this is just a quick refresher overview so the idea
behind ongoing is that we have a single sidecar proxy self-contained server like
nginx or h a proxy the idea here is that all the things that I show you on that
previous slide you can implement in one place so you can have you know complicated retries timeouts back
pressure you can have consistent staff logging and tracing it you can have robust protocol support and you can do
this all in one place and from a service perspective service only knows about envoy so the service will talk to its
local envoy will send requests envoy will do load balancing service discovery all of these things and then it'll get
the response and will return that response to the service so from the service perspective it's a very powerful
paradigm because for the most part the service does not need to be aware of the actual network so let's do just a quick
rundown of envoy features so like I was saying before as an out of process architecture so we are not doing a
library approach the benefit here being for slight degradation and performance
people always ask what's the performance overhead again it depends on on what what you're doing and what is considered
but let's say that it's you know less than one millisecond to hop for cyclins degradation the benefits
that you get from being able to deploy changes everywhere to have a consistent feature set is super super powerful it's
written in C++ 11 modern code base very fast very very productive at its core
envoy is actually an l3 l4 filter based architecture so it's really a byte proxy
and the reason that's interesting that you can build up complicated filters that do different protocols so for
example we can support rest we can support you can see but we can also support MongoDB reddit s tunnel my
sequel whatever obviously rest is a huge huge part of the modern internet so
envoy supports a huge amount of functionality at that later so we have a
whole l7 filter stack you know to operate on things like headers and body and trailer envoy is an h2 proxy first
which is relatively novel for modern but roxies most proxy that exists today were
built in an h1 universe and as it turns out doing by you know proxy back and
forth from H 1 to H 2 and H 2 to H 1 can be actually quite quite complicated so envoy was built with that from the
get-go and that allows us to work with a large large number of different protocols we do service discovery
obviously and we do a combination of active and passive health checking so active health checking is out-of-band
things like requesting the slash health check endpoint passive health checking is actually monitoring in band traffic
so for example if you receive the three consecutive five hundreds in a row you might boot a day back at house we do a
whole bunch of advanced load balancing features so these are things like retry timeouts circuit breaks and rate
limiting by shadowing outlier detection and most importantly and you're going to hear me say this over and over and over
again it's all about a serve ability so envoy does a huge number of stats logging and we also form a trace route
and currently we have trace support for the skin as well as light Scott we don't
currently have Prometheus support that's something that people have been asking for a lot on Twitter recently we would
love to see that added and a right so from a staff perspective the current
staff provider is that's deep but again would love to see different providers there and an envoy is also very usable
as an edge proxy which means that we've invested a lot in edge TLS features this
turns out to be very important because a lot of companies historically they use something like nginx at the edge and
then they use a chip proxy internally and what that means from an Operations perspective is that operation staff need
to learn how to operate two very different proxies as it turns out ninety
percent of what these things do from an internal load balancer perspective and from an edge perspective are the same so
having the same software be runnable in both places is very very powerful from a ops perspective all right so one
of the primary goals of envoy is really that it is kind of a cool Universal data
plane and by that I mean that envoy supports a set of api's that can
integrate with various management systems kind of to do general data plane processing and you know that that ends
up being very important because you know when you're down at the base data plane layer you can support a large variety of
different features but as you get closer and closer to the customer things just naturally become a little more opinionated right so if you're if you're
on premise you're going to need different configuration management and then if you're doing something like this do so you know having a set of API that
are simple and easy to implement and allow different management systems to actually control on whether motely end
up being very powerful so the v1 version of the API that we have are based on
JSON rest and we have four different API s one of them is the service discovery
service STS this is historical and poorly named this is basically a mechanism by which envoy can
look up back and host by name you can think of it as like DNS plus plus we have the cluster discovery service API
this allows envoy to discover all of the backend clusters clusters are set to
posts so for example you know the user service or day location service or the
officers we have the route discovery service this allows us to kind of learn
about l7 route tables and then we have the listener discovery service that lets us actually discover entire listeners
meaning listen on a particular report and set up by particularly chain so for
example you know give me some rate limiting give it some buffering routing etc we've been working with Google and
we're moving now towards kind of a set of v2 API s and the goal of the of the
v2 API is to make them strongly-typed vhe RPC will also support json we'd like
to support bi-directional streaming but in general they're really the same as v1 but the main benefits again are this
bi-directional streaming so that we don't have to do polling strongly-typed api's and enhanced features and some of
the things that we're doing here are working towards the endpoint discovery service EDS it will replace SDS so it's
quite similar basically DNS plus plus but because bi-directional will actually
be able to report host load info and that will allow the management system or a global go balancer to actually make
more more intelligent boss then we've
got the cluster discovery service API that's very similar RDS similar LDS similar we're adding the health
discovery service this will allow envoy to actually be used as part of a centralized get
distributed health checking system so a management server could assign a subset
of envoys to help check back end notes report that information to a central management server and then make those
health decisions and finally will be working on the aggregated discovery service the 80s and the idea here is
that we can allow all of the different streaming kind of API to be served by a
single stream and this is useful for management servers that would like things to happen in a particular order
so for example CBS could be followed with EDS to be followed with RTS or kind
of no no drop sequencing all right let's talk a little bit about history the
project was born in May of 15 we open
source in September of 16 as of yesterday we have 69 contributors
there's two orbs which commits access that is list and Google I like to joke

envoy we deploy envoy tens of thousands of posts hundreds of services we
regularly do about 3 million requests per second across the lift mesh from a
competitive standpoint the primary competitors to envoy or nginx h a proxy
obviously the cloud load balancing solutions smart stack linker key as well as traffic
envoy differentiates from these solutions by a focusing on performance it's extremely high performance it has
equal or greater performance nginx all of HAF proxy and then from a
